channel.title: Simplifying XML DTD
channel.description:
I was just wondering if there was a way to reduce duplicate attribute declarations in a DTD. Here's what i'm working with
[code=DTD] <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!ELEMENT nodes ((node_a|node_b)+) > <!ELEMENT node_a EMPTY> <!ATTLIST node_a id CDATA #REQUIRED>
<!ELEMENT node_b EMPTY> <!ATTLIST node_b id CDATA #REQUIRED> [/code]
Is there a way to declare the attribute [i]id[/i] only once? I tried doing [code=DTD] <!ATTLIST (node_a,node_b) id CDATA #REQUIRED> [/code] and [code=DTD] <!ATTLIST (node_a|node_b) id CDATA #REQUIRED> [/code]
But it didn't validate.

item.title: Simplifying XML DTD
item.dc:creator: @The_Outsider The Outsider
item.description:
@The_Outsider wrote:

XML is overrated. I have a 300mb NPCDefinitions.xml and it takes over 3 minutes to load, 3 minutes to edit, 3 minutes to scroll. It’s become impractical.

Read full topic

item.title: Simplifying XML DTD
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

You didn’t have a point, nor can you ever ‘answer’ a point. If you’re implying what I said somehow supported your claim, you should re-read what I said in perhaps a different way, because I was saying that your logic was fallacious (as I said less aerodynamic, but you were implying the person would mean ‘more’) and that it was completely irrelevant in the first place.

Oh, and me replying to it doesn’t make it relevant.

And I’d like to continue on the second part more, as in why you think enums are overrated.

XML is overrated because it’s only useful for structure design and storing some data - and depending on what you’re storing, sometimes your XML tags can take up more space than your data itself… making it more overhead than content where you could much more easily use some sort of database servers to get the job done faster. And then if you’re storing all of the data in your program, you get even MORE overhead (except this time in memory instead of hard), unless you parse live-action, in which case your processing times are going to go up exponentially. It depends what you use it for really, but for the most part I’ve found either just putting my data into my programming language directly for smaller sets of data or using database software (like [My?]SQL[ite?]) for larger sets tends to be a better option

Just my personal experience.

Read full topic

item.title: Simplifying XML DTD
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

Davidi2:

Attaching a Dixie cup to a rocket ship would not make it at all noticeably less aerodynamic, so that person would obviously be a moron. Or you could just call them a moron for not giving any reasons that relate to the subject at hand

Totally relevant subject, you just answered my point.

Read full topic

item.title: Simplifying XML DTD
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:9, topic:424982”][quote author=sinisoul link=topic=527645.msg3846765#msg3846765 date=1323668079]

I don’t see how that’s relevant. Though really all enums are is just sub classes with predefined final instances… so I don’t see how they can be overrated OR underrated

there is a point in which you can abuse them
[/quote]Some would just call it object oriented programming instead of overusing arrays, when you’re avoiding using an external scripting language[/quote]

Some would call it attaching a dixie cup to a rocket ship and calling it aerodynamic.

item.title: Simplifying XML DTD
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

I was just wondering if there was a way to reduce duplicate attribute declarations in a DTD. Here’s what i’m working with

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<!ELEMENT nodes ((node_a|node_b)+) >
<!ELEMENT node_a EMPTY>
<!ATTLIST node_a id CDATA #REQUIRED>

<!ELEMENT node_b EMPTY>
<!ATTLIST node_b id CDATA #REQUIRED>

Is there a way to declare the attribute id only once? I tried doing

<!ATTLIST (node_a,node_b) id CDATA #REQUIRED>

and

<!ATTLIST (node_a|node_b) id CDATA #REQUIRED>

But it didn’t validate.

Read full topic
